`_update_params_on_kvstore` means we will update the parameters by the optimizer set in the kvstore, namely by kvstore.set_optimizer(optimizer)

@tqchen sure I can add `ProdShape` to `TShape`. But I'm wondering maybe we should also "fix" `FlatTo2D` -- either change the doc or its implementation. Currently the doc says

``` cpp
175   /*!
176    * flatten the higher dimension to second dimension, return a 2D shape
177    * \return the flat 2d shape
178    */
```

It seems the doc is indicating a different behavior from the current implementation. In the context of deep learning where the first dimension is samples, the behavior in the doc makes more sense. But I'm not sure how widely this function is used, so changing it might breaks a lot of the existing stuff. An alternative is to keep the current implementation but fix the doc.

let us fix the doc, so things can be compatible

@tornadomeet  @piiswrong  

I had defined my Offset as follows

def offset():
    conv1_1_fp = filter_map(kernel=3, pad=100)
    conv1_2_fp = conv2_1_fp = conv2_2_fp = conv3_1_fp = conv3_2_fp = conv3_3_fp \
               = conv5_1_fp = conv5_2_fp \
               = conv5_3_fp = filter_map(kernel=3, pad=1)
    pool1_fp = pool2_fp = pool3_fp = pool5_fp = filter_map(kernel=2, stride=2)
    fc6_fp = filter_map(kernel=5)
    fc7_fp = score_fp = score_pool3_fp = filter_map()
    # for fcn-32s
    fcn32s_upscore_fp = inv_fp(filter_map(kernel=4, stride=1))
    fcn32s_upscore_list = [conv1_1_fp, conv1_2_fp, pool1_fp, conv2_1_fp, conv2_2_fp,
                           pool2_fp, conv3_1_fp, conv3_2_fp, conv3_3_fp, pool3_fp,
                           conv5_1_fp, conv5_2_fp, conv5_3_fp, pool5_fp, fc6_fp, fc7_fp, score_fp,
                           fcn32s_upscore_fp]
    crop = {}
    crop["fcn32s_upscore"] = (-int(round(compose_fp_list(fcn32s_upscore_list)[1])),
                              -int(round(compose_fp_list(fcn32s_upscore_list)[1])))
    return crop

@Godricly Good point! Yes, it seems the computation code also uses `FlatTo2D`, and needs to be fixed.

@piiswrong Yes. A module is (essentially the same as `FeedForward`) like a container a symbol, considered a huge operator, that could be manipulated easily with imperative API. Ideally we will have other container modules that could compose other modules using imperative API. This is useful, for example, for implementing back-prop through time.
Ok, Thanks!

I come to this question when I try to implement the ROIPooling layer used in Fast and Faster RCNN (https://github.com/rbgirshick/caffe-fast-rcnn/blob/fast-rcnn/src/caffe/layers/roi_pooling_layer.cu). The backward operation of ROIPooling may be easier to implement if we know the argmax indices. Also, when we pool over a large region, e.g global pooling, the current way of getting the pooled indices may not be efficient.

So bucketing support for prediction will be available soon. Implementing BPTT with high-level API might also become easy by then. Let us talk after I come back.

By test, i found the argument "is_train=True" in forward op is very crucial. When i setted "is_train=True", i can get the correct result, otherwise there were many mistakes. 
But i noticed that the argument "is_train"in forward op aren't set  "True" in example(Neural-style)code,  and the results are still correct. I'm very confused about this argument "is_train". So the question become what's the specific usage of argument "is_train" in forward op?
Thanks a lot!

It depends on the network you loaded. Most likely it takes 1 dim input while you are feeding 2 dim.
You can try NDArrayIter. It's easier to work with.
If you want to call backward afterwards you should set is_train to True.

You can store the indexes as an second output, but remember to make it invisible.
Please refer to BatchNorm layer for example.

Use mx.init.Mixed()

Xavier specify the range, you still need to pick a method that init each variable with that range.

It's not possible.
You don't need multithreaded training. Every operation on NDArrays is async. They are automatically parallelized by the engine.
looks good to me.
when you change c_api it's usually better to make a new one, like MXKVStoreRunServerEx. Otherwise it will break all the other language interfaces.

Example for NDArrayIter.
You may need to modify the parameter of np.reshape to fit your network.

```
data = cv2.imread(imagepath)    # check if the size of image is 28x28
data = data.transpose((2,0,1))
data = data[0:1,:,:]
print data.shape    # (1, 28, 28)

data = np.reshape(data,(1,1,28,28))    # for lenet (batchsize, ch, height, width)
#data = np.reshape(data,(1,784))    # for mlp

dataiter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data)
r = model.predict(dataiter)
print r
```

@GrindstoneLZX The memory should already been shared across buckets -- essentially, the total memory consumption should be equal to the largest bucket (e.g. the longest sequence). Can you try to set the longest sequence to be of the same length in all the cases to see if the memory still grows noticeably with the number of buckets?

BTW: that mechanism are you using the measure the device memory? We are also interested in doing some more test on the memory consumption, but did not get good way to measure the device memory usage yet.

I looked at the torch code a little bit closer today. I think it might make more sense to implement it using an imperative control flow here. Because for bucketing, you might end up with exponential number of buckets.

I'm currently working on a new module API which will potentially make this kind of imperative control easier. I might be able to come up with a simple demo of this stochastic depth within a week using the new API.

One potential overhead is that Lua is a tiny language comparing to Python. So imperative scheduling might have slightly more overhead than the Lua code. We will see.

I use Tesla K40 for my experiments and I measure GPU memory usage by simply using 'nvidia-smi' to observe the maximum usage during training.
In all caces I use the same dataset. My dataset is a speech dataset with 4620 utterances, and the frame number (sequence length) of each utterance ranges from 54 to 487. I set buckets in a way that the number of utterances is roughly equal in each bucket. For example:

| bucket[0] | bucket[1] | bucket[2] | ... | bucket[N-2] | bucket[N-1] |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 89 | 126 | 178 | ... | 321 | 487 |

the default_bucket_key of my DataIter is **bucket[0]**. During training, first I select one bucket and then select several utterances as one mini-batch. If the mini-batch is not full, I will fill it with zeros. I have tried two different way to select buckets. 
The result I reported yesterday is the selecting buckets in an ascending order, which is **89, 126, 178, ... , 321, 487**. 

And I also tried descending order, which is **487, 321, ..., 178, 126, 89**. The result is:

| GPU memory (MB) | parallel_num = 25 | parallel_num = 40 | parallel_num = 60 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| bucket_num = 10 | 3321 | 5454 | 7080 |
| bucket_num = 20 | 3638 | 5945 | 7846 |
| bucket_num = 50 | 3568 | 5881 | 7699 |
| bucket_num = 70 | 3553 | 5774 | 7658 |
| bucket_num = 100 | 3537 | 5728 | 7626 |

![memory usage 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18130064/14339296/1e6d7b28-fcb0-11e5-963c-a622726b6367.png)

And I also tried random order, the memory usage is random too. 

I tried to set default_bucket_key to buckets[N-1] to pre-allocate maximum memory space, but when I set default_bucket_key = buckets[N-1], I get an error:

Not sure why it got compiled with `-fopenmp` even though you disabled it in `config.mk`. Clang does not officially support openmp yet.

Just in case it helps, here's the full output from the terminal: [mxnet_bash_output.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/208879/mxnet_bash_output.txt)

It seems it is trying to compile dmlc-core with `-fopenmp`, even though openmp is disabled. I'm not sure what is happening here. As in `Makefile` we have

```
ifneq ($(USE_OPENMP), 1)
        export NO_OPENMP = 1
endif

# use customized config file
include $(config)
include mshadow/make/mshadow.mk
include $(DMLC_CORE)/make/dmlc.mk
unexport NO_OPENMP
```

and in `dmlc-core/make/dmlc.mk`, we have

```
ifndef NO_OPENMP
        DMLC_CFLAGS += -fopenmp
        DMLC_LDFLAGS += -fopenmp
endif
```

So `-fopenmp` should not be used. I am able to compile with Clang on OS X without problem. :-/
- If some of the states are exclusive to each other, maybe consider using enum style as opposed to indicator bools

One thing we did not consider carefully before is how to use metrics for multiple outputs. 
- For RNN cases, the metrics need to be summed up
- For multiple output nets, maybe separate  is needed? or a customization is needed for the metric of multiple outputs.

@tqchen Only three states are related. `binded`, `param_initialized` and `optimizer_initialized`. They are kind of stages. For example, parameters cannot be initialized before executors are binded. Maybe enums could be used, but I am not sure if it could simplify.

Yes metrics should also be updated. Ideally user should write metric for the specific task, as it is usually simple Python code. But maybe allowing the metric to access more information (e.g. bucket key) might help its implementation.

- As long as we have a clear instruction on how to define metric, it is fine.
- Use enum can avoid possible bad state (e.g. binded=False and initialized=True). Apart from that, it is OK to use the bools
line 140, it should be 'arg.initial_image' rather than 'arg.start_image' @JacobEdelman

compile mxnet with openmp
I used cmake on a ubuntu box.

I compiled mxnet with USE_OPENMP = 1 
After some profiling i realized that MXPredForward takes only 0.04 seconds for a single image but
MXPredGetOutput takes a lot of time about 1 second for one image. This function copies the result data after prediction
( https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/5ff545f2345f9b607b81546a168665bd63d02d9f/src/c_api/c_predict_api.cc )

Any way to make this fast?
This was an warning to enable the efficient aggregation and save memory. The message was a hint for this experimental feature. It is likely you can benefit from switching it on
can you post your code using mx.io.NDArrayIter? It should work out of box
closing for now, please feel free to reopen it

If you are training on big image dataset, it is possible for mxnet to allocate some memory for caching and there are multiple layers of caching and pre-fetching.

This is likely to be caused by ImageRecordIter and it was fixed a bit by latest version. Some configurations can be fine tuned to reduce the memory consumption.

You can try to set the following options to be smaller value (c.f. http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html#mxnet.io.ImageRecordIter)
- prefetch_buffer 
- preprocess_threads

@GrindstoneLZX sorry I don't quite understand what your figure mean. Setting default bucket to be the largest one might be a good way to try. Please remember when you set the default bucket, the `provide_data` and `provide_label` on the DataIter should match that of the default bucket. Can you double check that? Thanks!

@lxduan have you found a resolution?

You probably have a previous version of the library in `/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages`].  If so, just do:

```
$ pip uninstall mxnet
$ pwd
/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages
$ sudo rm -rf ./mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg 
```

then rebuild mxnet and you should be able to run the example after setting up `$PYTHONPATH`.
